intro: Sida vespertina, commonly known as evening sida, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States and parts of Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant produces small, pink to purple flowers that bloom in the late afternoon, hence its common name. Its leaves are ovate and covered in fine hairs, and it typically grows in moist, sandy soils. Sida vespertina is often found in coastal areas and is adapted to thrive in saline environments.
